title: Data structures visualizer

buttons.undo-title: Undo the last operation. Wait for the current operation to finish before undoing

about.abstract-data-types-description: Abstract Data Types (ADTs) are a way to define a data structure in terms of the operations that can be performed on it, without specifying how these operations are implemented. This allows for a clear separation between the interface and the implementation of the data structure.
about.abstract-data-types-note: <important>Important</important>: This does not show a full ADT/CDT, only the underlying data strucures. In a real implementation, things like size/iteration fields would likely be present
about.abstract-data-types-pdf-guide: <pdf>PDF Guide with notes and drawings (in Spanish)</pdf>
about.visualization-description: Here you can visualize the behavior of some of the most common data structures. You can create new instances, perform operations on them and see how they change in real time.
about.visualization-available-actions: Some operations are available on all data structures, like Search. Others may see their behaviour altered (for example a List may `insert` but a Queue will only `insert-last`). The operations displayed on the menu will correspond to the selected data types

created-by: Created as a visual aid for the Imperative Programming course at ITBA (72.31).
